column1: say;verb;seɪ;<image src='say_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:say_ed_eng.mp3];to pronounce words or sounds
column2: to express a thought
column3: opinion
column4: or suggestion
column5:
or to state a fact or instruction: ; ;[sound:say_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
Small children find it difficult to say long words.
column6: She said goodbye to all her friends and left.
column7: Ben never forgets to say ""Please"" and ""Thank you"".
column8: How do you say ""goodbye"" in French?
column11: Do you know what she said to him?
column12: What did they say about the house?
column13: [ + speech ] ""I'm going out this evening
column15: He said to himself (= thought)
column17: [ + (that) ] The doctors say (that) it will take him a few weeks to recover.
column18: [ + question word ] She didn't say whether she was coming.
column19: Did she say (= tell you) why she wasn't coming?
column20: [ + to infinitive ] informal He said (= told me) to meet him here.
column21: I've got something to say to you.
column22:
The offer was so good that I couldn't say no (= couldn't refuse).
";[sound:say_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: say;exclamation;seɪ;<image src='say_exclamation_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:say_ed_eng.mp3];used to express surprise or pleasure
column2:
or to attract attention to what you are about to say: ; ;[sound:say_exclamation_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
US Say
column3: that's really good of you!
column4: US Say
column5: how about going out tonight?
column6: UK I say
column7: what a splendid hat you're wearing!";[sound:say_exclamation_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1:
say;noun;seɪ;;[sound:say_ed_eng.mp3];(the right to give) an opinion about something: ; ;[sound:say_noun_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
Keep quiet for a minute and let me have my say.
column2:
The judge usually has the final say.
";[sound:say_noun_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: tell;verb;tel;<image src='tell_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:tell_ed_eng.mp3];to say something to someone
column2:
often giving them information or instructions: ; ;[sound:tell_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
Tell me about your holiday then.
column3: [ + two objects ] Can you tell me how to get to the library?
column4: [ + obj + (that) ] Did you tell anyone (that) you were coming to see me?
column5: [ + obj + speech ] ""I'm leaving you
column6: she told him.
column7: [ + obj + to infinitive ] I told her to go home.
column8: formal He told us of his extraordinary childhood.
column9:
I can't tell you how grateful I am for your help (= I am extremely grateful).
";[sound:tell_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1:
agree;verb;əˈɡriː;;[sound:agree_ed_eng.mp3];to have the same opinion: ; ;[sound:agree_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
Ann and I never seem to agree.
column2: I agree with you on this issue.
column3: My father and I don't agree about/on very much.
column4: [ + that ] I agree that he should be invited.
column5: [ + question word ] Experts seem unable to agree whether the drug is safe or not.
column6: [ + speech ] ""You're absolutely right
column7: agreed Jake.";[sound:agree_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: claim;verb;kleɪm;<image src='claim_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:claim_ed_eng.mp3];to say that something is true or is a fact
column2:
although you cannot prove it and other people might not believe it: ; ;[sound:claim_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
[ + (that) ] The company claims (that) it is not responsible for the pollution in the river.
column3: [ + to infinitive ] He claims to have met the president
column4: but I don't believe him.
column5: All parties have claimed success in yesterday's elections.
column6:
An unknown terrorist group has claimed responsibility for this morning's bomb attack.
";[sound:claim_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: claim;noun;kleɪm;<image src='claim_noun_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:claim_ed_eng.mp3];a statement that something is true or is a fact
column2: although other people might not believe it: ; ;[sound:claim_noun_def_ed_eng.mp3];"<div class=""examp dexamp""><span class=""eg deg"">He said the police assaulted him while he was in custody
column3: a claim that the police deny.
column4: [ + that ] The government's claim that it would reduce taxes proved false.
column5: Can you give any evidence to support your claim?
column6:
He made wild claims about being able to cure cancer.
";[sound:claim_noun_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1:
promise;verb;ˈprɒm.ɪs;;[sound:promise_ed_eng.mp3];to tell someone that you will certainly do something: ; ;[sound:promise_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
[ + to infinitive ] He promised faithfully to call me every week.
column2: [ + that ] The government have promised that they'll reduce taxes.
column3: [ + (that) ] Promise me (that) you won't tell him.
column4: I'll look for some while I'm at the shops but I'm not promising anything.
column5: Can I have that book back when you've finished because I've promised it (= I have said I will give it) to Sara.
column6: [ + two objects ] Her parents promised her a new car if she passed her exams.
column7: I've promised myself a long bath when I get through all this work.
column8: [ + speech ] ""I'll come round and see you every day
column10: ""I won't do anything dangerous."" ""You promise?"" ""I promise.""
column11:
""I won't have time to take you shopping this afternoon."" ""But you promised!""
";[sound:promise_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1:
promise;noun;ˈprɒm.ɪs;;[sound:promise_ed_eng.mp3];the act of saying that you will certainly do something: ; ;[sound:promise_noun_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
I'll put my things away tonight - and that's a promise!
column2: <div class=""examp dexamp""> <span class=""eg deg"">I'll try to get back in time
column3: but I'm not making any promises.";[sound:promise_noun_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: refuse;verb;rɪˈfjuːz;<image src='refuse_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:refuse_ed_eng.mp3];to say that you will not do or accept something: ; ;[sound:refuse_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"<div class=""examp dexamp""><span class=""eg deg"">He asked me to give him another loan
column2: but I refused.
column3: He's in trouble but he's refused all (my offers of) help.
column4: [ + to infinitive ] On cold mornings the car always refuses to start.
column5:
[ + two objects ] The local council refused him planning permission to build an extra bedroom.
";[sound:refuse_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: refuse;noun;ˈref.juːs;<image src='refuse_noun_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:refuse_ed_eng.mp3];unwanted waste material
column2: especially material that is regularly thrown away from a house
column3: factory
column4:
etc.: ; ;[sound:refuse_noun_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
garden/kitchen refuse
";[sound:refuse_noun_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: swear;verb;sweər;<image src='swear_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:swear_ed_eng.mp3];to use words that are rude or offensive as a way of emphasizing what you mean or as a way of insulting someone or something: ; ;[sound:swear_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"<div class=""examp dexamp""><span class=""eg deg"">It was a real shock
column2: the first time I heard my mother swear.
column3: When the cab driver started to swear at him
column4: he walked away.";[sound:swear_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1:
threaten;verb;ˈθret.ən;;[sound:threaten_ed_eng.mp3];to tell someone that you will kill or hurt them or cause problems if they do not do what you want: ; ;[sound:threaten_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
They threatened the shopkeeper with a gun.
column2:
[ + to infinitive ] They threatened to kill him unless he did as they asked.
";[sound:threaten_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: admit;verb;ədˈmɪt;<image src='admit_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:admit_ed_eng.mp3];to agree that something is true
column2:
especially unwillingly: ; ;[sound:admit_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
He admitted his guilt/mistake.
column3: [ + (that) ] She admitted (that) she had made a mistake.
column4: [ + -ing verb ] She admitted making a mistake.
column5: At first he denied stealing the money but he later admitted (to) it.
column6: <div class=""examp dexamp""> <span class=""eg deg"">I wasn't entirely honest with him
column7: I admit.
column8:
[ + to infinitive ] The new law was generally admitted to be difficult to enforce.
";[sound:admit_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: answer;noun;ˈɑːn.sər;<image src='answer_noun_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:answer_ed_eng.mp3];a reaction to a question
column2: letter
column3: phone call
column4:
etc.: ; ;[sound:answer_noun_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
The minister promised to give a written answer to the MP's detailed question.
column5: We've emailed him asking him if he's free on that date but we haven't had an answer yet.
column6: I've just called him but there was no answer.
column7: I didn't realize we had to write each answer on a new sheet of paper.
column8: I got eight correct answers and two wrong ones in last week's exam.
column9: In answer to your letter of 30 May
column10: I am writing to accept your offer of £3

column1: answer;verb;ˈɑːn.sər;<image src='answer_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:answer_ed_eng.mp3];to say
column2: write
column3: or do something as a reaction to a question
column4: letter
column5:
etc.: ; ;[sound:answer_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
I can't answer (you) without more detailed information.
column6: You haven't answered my question.
column7: I texted asking whether he'd be coming to the party but he hasn't answered yet.
column8: [ + speech ] ""I'd love to have dinner with you
column9: but I won't be able to get there before nine o'clock
column11: [ + that ] She answered that she wouldn't be able to come before nine o'clock.
column12:
formal Does anyone here answer to the name of (= is anyone here called) Wallis?
";[sound:answer_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1:
confess;verb;kənˈfes;;[sound:confess_ed_eng.mp3];to admit that you have done something wrong or something that you feel guilty or bad about: ; ;[sound:confess_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
[ + that ] She confessed to her husband that she had sold her wedding ring.
column2: He confessed to sleeping/having slept through most of the movie.
column3: He has confessed to the murder.
column4: [ + (that) ] I have to confess (that) when I first met Reece I didn't think he was very bright.
column5: <div class=""examp dexamp""> <span class=""eg deg"">It was all very confusing
column6: I must confess.";[sound:confess_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1:
deny;verb;dɪˈnaɪ;;[sound:deny_ed_eng.mp3];to say that something is not true: ; ;[sound:deny_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
He will not confirm or deny the allegations.
column2: [ + that ] Neil denies that he broke the window
column3: but I'm sure he did.
column4:
[ + -ing verb ] Neil denies breaking the window.
";[sound:deny_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: recommend;verb;ˌrek.əˈmend;<image src='recommend_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:recommend_ed_eng.mp3];to suggest that someone or something would be good or suitable for a particular job or purpose
column2:
or to suggest that a particular action should be done: ; ;[sound:recommend_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
I can recommend the chicken in mushroom sauce - it's delicious.
column3: She has been recommended for promotion.
column4: The headmistress agreed to recommend the teachers' proposals to the school governors.
column5: [ + (that) ] The doctor recommended (that) I get more exercise.
column6: [ + -ing verb ] I recommend writing your feelings down on paper.
column7:
The city has much/little to recommend it (= it has many/few pleasant qualities).
";[sound:recommend_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1:
remind;verb;rɪˈmaɪnd;;[sound:remind_ed_eng.mp3];to make someone think of something they have forgotten or might have forgotten: ; ;[sound:remind_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
Could you remind Paul about dinner on Saturday?
column2: [ + to infinitive ] Please remind me to post this letter.
column3:
[ + (that) ] I called Jane and reminded her (that) the conference had been cancelled.
";[sound:remind_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: warn;verb;wɔːn;<image src='warn_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:warn_ed_eng.mp3];to make someone realize a possible danger or problem
column2:
especially one in the future: ; ;[sound:warn_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
[ + obj + to infinitive ] We were warned not to eat the fish which might upset our stomachs.
column3: [ + obj + (that) ] Have you warned them (that) there will be an extra person for dinner?
column4: I was warned against/off going to the east coast because it was so full of tourists.
column5: The boating area is marked with buoys to warn off swimmers.
column6: There were signs warning of fog as soon as we got onto the motorway.
column7: This particular curry is extremely hot - be warned!
column8: <div class=""examp dexamp""> <span class=""eg deg"">Put that ball down now
column9: Laura - I'm warning you (= I will punish you if you do not)!";[sound:warn_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: accuse;verb;əˈkjuːz;<image src='accuse_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:accuse_ed_eng.mp3];to say that someone has done something morally wrong
column2: illegal
column3: or unkind: ; ;[sound:accuse_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"<div class=""examp dexamp""><span class=""eg deg"">""It wasn't my fault."" ""Don't worry
column4: I'm not accusing you.""
column5: He's been accused of robbery/murder.
column6: Are you accusing me of lying?
column7:
The surgeon was accused of negligence.
";[sound:accuse_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1:
blame;verb;bleɪm;;[sound:blame_ed_eng.mp3];to say or think that someone or something did something wrong or is responsible for something bad happening: ; ;[sound:blame_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
Don't blame me (= it is not my fault) if you miss the bus!
column2: Hugh blames his mother for his lack of confidence.
column3:
Hugh blames his lack of confidence on his mother.
";[sound:blame_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1:
blame;noun;bleɪm;;[sound:blame_ed_eng.mp3];the situation in which people say or think that someone or something did something wrong or is responsible for something bad happening: ; ;[sound:blame_noun_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
Health officials put the blame for the disease on (= say that the reason for the disease is) poor housing conditions.
column2: They tried to pin (= put) the blame for the killing on an innocent army officer.
column3: <div class=""examp dexamp""> <span class=""eg deg"">We want to find out what happened
column4: not to apportion blame (= to say someone or something was wrong).";[sound:blame_noun_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1:
complain;verb;kəmˈpleɪn;;[sound:complain_ed_eng.mp3];to say that something is wrong or not satisfactory: ; ;[sound:complain_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
Lots of people have complained about the noise.
column2: You're always complaining!
column3:
[ + that ] He complained that his boss was useless and he had too much work.
";[sound:complain_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: regret;noun;rɪˈɡret;<image src='regret_noun_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:regret_ed_eng.mp3];a feeling of sadness about something sad or wrong or about a mistake that you have made
column2: and a wish that it could have been different and better: ; ;[sound:regret_noun_def_ed_eng.mp3];"<div class=""examp dexamp""><span class=""eg deg"">I left school at 16
column3: but I've had a great life and I have no regrets.
column4: The manager expressed deep regret at/for the number of staff reductions.
column5: <div class=""examp dexamp""> <span class=""eg deg"">We think
column6: much to our regret (= and we are very sorry about this)
column7: that we will not be able to visit you next year.";[sound:regret_noun_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: regret;verb;rɪˈɡret;<image src='regret_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:regret_ed_eng.mp3];to feel sorry about a situation
column2:
especially something sad or wrong or a mistake that you have made: ; ;[sound:regret_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
Is there anything you've done in your life that you regret?
column3: [ + -ing verb ] I have always regretted not having studied harder at school.
column4: [ + (that) ] formal The council regrets (that) the money to subsidize the youth club is no longer available.
column5:
[ + to infinitive ] formal British Airways regret to announce the cancellation of flight BA205 to Madrid.
";[sound:regret_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: insist;verb;ɪnˈsɪst;<image src='insist_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:insist_ed_eng.mp3];to say firmly or demand forcefully
column2:
especially when others disagree with or oppose what you say: ; ;[sound:insist_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
[ + (that) ] Greg still insists (that) he did nothing wrong.
column3: Please go first - I insist!
column4:
She insisted on seeing her lawyer.
";[sound:insist_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: suggest;verb;səˈdʒest;<image src='suggest_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:suggest_ed_eng.mp3];to mention an idea
column2: possible plan
column3:
or action for other people to consider: ; ;[sound:suggest_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
I suggested an Italian restaurant near the station for the party.
column4: formal Might I suggest a white wine with your salmon
column5: sir?
column6: [ + (that) ] I suggest (that) we wait a while before we make any firm decisions.
column7: Liz suggested (that) I try the shop on Mill Road.
column8: [ + -ing verb ] I suggested putting the matter to the committee.
column9:
[ + question word ] Can you suggest where I could buy a dozen roses?
";[sound:suggest_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1:
advise;verb;ədˈvaɪz;;[sound:advise_ed_eng.mp3];to give someone advice: ; ;[sound:advise_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
[ + to infinitive ] I think I'd advise him to leave the company.
column2: His doctor advised him against smoking.
column3: I'd strongly advise against making a sudden decision.
column4: [ + that ] They're advising that children be kept at home.
column5: [ + -ing verb ] I'd advise waiting until tomorrow.
column6: [ + question word ] She advised us when to come.
column7: She advises the president (= gives information and suggests types of action) on African policy.
column8:
You would be well advised to (= it would be wise for you to) have the appropriate vaccinations before you go abroad.
";[sound:advise_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: ask;verb;ɑːsk;<image src='ask_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:ask_ed_eng.mp3];to put a question to someone
column2:
or to request an answer from someone: ; ;[sound:ask_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
[ + two objects ] She asked me a question.
column3: She asked a question about Welsh history.
column4: She asked me about Welsh history.
column5: She asked about Welsh history.
column6: [ + question word ] I've no idea what time the train leaves. Ask the guard whether he knows.
column7: I asked the guard the time of the train's departure.
column8: I asked when the train would leave.
column9:
[ + speech ] ""What time does the train leave?"" I asked.
";[sound:ask_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1:
beg;verb;beɡ;;[sound:beg_ed_eng.mp3];to make a very strong and urgent request: ; ;[sound:beg_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
They begged for mercy.
column2: [ + speech ] ""Please
column3: please forgive me!"" she begged (him).
column4: [ + obj + to infinitive ] He begged her to stay
column5: but she simply laughed and put her bags in the car.";[sound:beg_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1:
convince;verb;kənˈvɪns;;[sound:convince_ed_eng.mp3];to persuade someone or make someone certain: ; ;[sound:convince_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
He managed to convince the jury of his innocence.
column2: [ + (that) ] It's useless trying to convince her (that) she doesn't need to lose any weight.
column3:
[ + to infinitive ] I hope this will convince you to change your mind.
";[sound:convince_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: encourage;verb;ɪnˈkʌr.ɪdʒ;<image src='encourage_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:encourage_ed_eng.mp3];to make someone more likely to do something
column2:
or to make something more likely to happen: ; ;[sound:encourage_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
[ T + to infinitive ] We were encouraged to learn foreign languages at school.
column3:
The council is encouraging the development of the property for both employment and recreation.
";[sound:encourage_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: forbid;verb;fəˈbɪd;<image src='forbid_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:forbid_ed_eng.mp3];to refuse to allow something
column2: especially officially
column3:
or to prevent a particular plan of action by making it impossible: ; ;[sound:forbid_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
The law forbids the sale of cigarettes to people under the age of 16.
column4: [ + to infinitive ] He's obviously really embarrassed about it because he forbade me to tell anyone.
column5:
He is forbidden from leaving the country.
";[sound:forbid_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1:
invite;verb;ɪnˈvaɪt;;[sound:invite_ed_eng.mp3];to ask or request someone to go to an event: ; ;[sound:invite_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
We're invited to Lola's party.
column2: Candidates who are successful in the written test will be invited for an interview.
column3:
[ + obj + to infinitive ] Her family invited me to stay with them for a few weeks.
";[sound:invite_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1:
invite;noun;ˈɪn.vaɪt;;[sound:invite_ed_eng.mp3];an invitation: ; ;[sound:invite_noun_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
I didn't get an invite to their wedding.
";[sound:invite_noun_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;
order;noun;ˈɔː.dər;<image src='order_noun_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:order_ed_eng.mp3];a request to make
column2: supply
column3:
or deliver food or goods: ; ;[sound:order_noun_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
""Can I take your order now?"" said the waiter.
column4:
I would like to place (= make) an order for a large pine table.
";[sound:order_noun_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: order;verb;ˈɔː.dər;<image src='order_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:order_ed_eng.mp3];to ask for something to be made
column2: supplied
column3: or delivered
column4:
especially in a restaurant or shop: ; ;[sound:order_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
I ordered some pasta and a mixed salad.
column5:
[ + two objects ] There are no shirts left in this size but we could order one for you/order you one.
";[sound:order_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: persuade;verb;pəˈsweɪd;<image src='persuade_verb_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:persuade_ed_eng.mp3];to make someone do or believe something by giving them a good reason to do it or by talking to that person and making them believe it: ; ;[sound:persuade_verb_def_ed_eng.mp3];"<div class=""examp dexamp""><span class=""eg deg"">If she doesn't want to go
column2: nothing you can say will persuade her.
column3: [ + (that) ] It's no use trying to persuade him (that) you're innocent.
column4: [ + to infinitive ] He is trying to persuade local and foreign businesses to invest in the project.
column5: <div class=""examp dexamp""> <span class=""eg deg"">Using a bunch of bananas
column6: the zoo-keeper persuaded the monkey back into its cage.
column7: formal The first priority is to persuade the management of the urgency of this matter.
column8:
Her legal advisers persuaded her into/out of mentioning (= to mention/not to mention) the names of the people involved in the robbery.
";[sound:persuade_verb_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1:
novel;noun;ˈnɒv.əl;;[sound:novel_ed_eng.mp3];a long printed story about imaginary characters and events: ; ;[sound:novel_noun_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
a paperback novel
column2: historical/romantic novels
column3: Have you read any of Jane Austen's novels?
column4:
His latest novel is selling really well.
";[sound:novel_noun_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: novel;adjective;ˈnɒv.əl;<image src='novel_adjective_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:novel_ed_eng.mp3];new and original
column2:
not like anything seen before: ; ;[sound:novel_adjective_def_ed_eng.mp3];"
a novel idea/suggestion
column3:
Keeping a sheep in the garden is a novel way of keeping the grass short!
";[sound:novel_adjective_ex_ed_eng.mp3]; ;

column1: pollen;noun;ˈpɒl.ən;<image src='pollen_noun_ed_eng.jpg'>;[sound:pollen_ed_eng.mp3];a powder
column2: produced by the male part of a flower
